Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Clustering, Classification and Alignment of Time Series for Human Sensing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Time series analysis is central to the study of computer vision, signal processing, computer graphics, machine learning, and social sciences, among other fields. This project entails original contributions towards algorithms for unsupervised pattern discovery and temporal alignment of time series, and its applications to model human motion. In particular, the PI proposes three new methods: (1) a discriminative temporal clustering that factorizes a set of time series into segments belonging to one of k temporal clusters, (2) a method for discovering the set of most discriminative segments between two sets of time series, and (3) an unsupervised algorithm for temporally aligning multi-modal time series. The PI proposes an energy minimization framework to encompass these three problems. This framework should provide researchers with a thorough understanding of a large number of existing time series techniques, and it may serve as a tool for dealing with other problems in time series as they arise.

Enabling computers to understand human behavior has the potential to revolutionize many areas that benefit society such as clinical diagnosis, human computer interaction, and social robotics. Advances in time series to model human actions and events from sensory data have been critical to the success of systems that can recognize and characterize human behavior. However, most existing algorithms have been supervised in nature. Supervised learning typically requires large amounts of human annotation, that is typically labor intensive and is difficult to standardize across coders. In this proposal the PI explores the use of unsupervised learning techniques for aligning and discovering patterns in time series of human motion that have been captured with accelerometers, video or motion capture technologies. The PI will show how the proposed algorithms outperform state-of-the-art techniques in several human sensing tasks such as temporal alignment of human motion, temporal clustering of human activities from video, learning motion primitives, and joint segmentation and classification of human behavior. In the educational aspect, the PI will continue to provide support to the Carnegie Science Center to demonstrate human sensing technologies, as well as incorporate a large number of undergraduates in his research. The research source code will be made available to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Time series analysis is central to the study of computer vision, signal processing, computer graphics, machine learning, and social sciences, as well as other fields. This project entails original contributions towards algorithms for supervised, weakly-supervised, unsupervised, and alignment of time series, and its applications to human sensing (e.g., expression analysis, activity recognition).

With this support, we have proposed several new problems and methods for time series analysis. The most important and novel contributions of this work are: (1) Weakly-supervised learning of time series analysis. Given a set of time series with positive and negative labels, our weakly-supervised learning algorithm discovers the most discriminative temporal segments between these two sets of time series. The algorithm has linear complexity in the length of the time series, and it is able to find discriminative patterns at different temporal scales. We applied this technique to discover the temporal segments that are most discriminative for activity recognition from video and accelerometer data. In addition, we showed that learning classifiers from the weakly-supervised discovered segments improve the classification performance. (2) Early event detection. Given an event of interest, we developed supervised algorithms to detect the event as soon as possible. This technique has particular interest when processing streaming data, and we applied it to early detection of facial expression and American sign language. This method won the best student paper award at IEEE Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition 2012.  (3) Temporal alignment of multi-modal data. Given multi-modal time series (e.g., video, accelerometers, motion capture data), we proposed an algorithm for accurate temporal alignment of these multi-modal and multi-dimensional time series. (4) Unsupervised clustering of time series. We extended traditional methods for spectral clustering to cluster time series. A main advantage of spectral methods is that they provide a natural embedding of the data, and the proposed method provides a new tool for visualizing time series. This technique has been applied to factorization of human motion into plausible motion primitives, that is central to understanding and building computational models of human motion.

The grant has resulted in seven top conference papers, three papers at IEEE Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence, and one at International Journal on Computer Vision. The research code has been made available at http://www.humansensing.cs.cmu.edu/software.html , and had more than 10,000 downloads.
